mechanical engineering during that same sort of frame of time had a 202 sorry
2000 increase in jobs so in the industrial revolution this was taking everyone it was doing agricultural
farming and moving them into factories so it was a huge need that was put upon
people to learn people to understand how to cooperate with one another in factories and all of this was really
quite new so there was a couple individuals that came out of this period that had some really big progressions in
sort of how groups would work well with one another and one of those guys was a man by the name of Frederick Winslow
Taylor so Taylor kind of has an interesting background he did not study formally
management or business or any of those things he actually applied to Harvard he got accepted and he ended up not going
because he had a deterioration in his eyesight so he decided to go into the factory and become a worker like hands
on and he worked for a while in the line with one else as a mechanical engineer and
then slowly worked his way up the chain and eventually became sort of chief engineer of a factory by the name of
Bethlehem Steel and during that time his experience sort of hands-on understanding kinds of the ins and outs
allowed him to come up with a lot of efficiency methods that are now we can
kind of see actually still in place today so one of the big ones with standardization you can kind of see a
parallel in that today we see a ton of standardization in software that makes us more efficient and capable of
collaborating more efficiently there is also a wonderful bit of work that was done by a couple by the name of Frank
and Lillian Gilbreth these are - if you've ever seen maybe Cheaper by the Dozen this is the story about them they
basically took their scientific management home to the workplace Lillian also is credited with sort of starting
the study of ergonomics in the factory so she did a lot of work there to sort of keep the factory workers in a place
where they can be happy and productive and efficient if anyone here has ever seen a Gantt chart Henry Gantt was the
creator of that he actually worked with Frederick R sari with Taylor at Bethlehem Steel and then a variety of
other things came about this wage incentives was a whole nother issue that came about because unions at the time were kind of struggling to figure out
how do we actually capture work that's done in factories and provide salaries
around it so there was a lot of work done there and ultimately all this led to things like Henry Ford's production
lines things like lean manufacturing and a lot of this has led into what we now
see in sort of agile software development but there's some bad in this - Taylor definitely was a stickler for
rapid efficiency so he was looking at things to the point where it kind of got
to the almost making humans machines side of things so he kind of went super
far in the scale of efficiency oftentimes to the disinterest of the individual and he also had a interesting
sort of approach where he felt that certain people were applicable for certain work and others were applicable for other work and if you take that to
the extreme that's basically eugenics so sort of something to watch out for there and then he also was a big proponent of
basically taking all decision-making power and giving it to management with very little input from the workers obviously we see where that can go wrong
and it kind of sparks some really dramatic strikes that happen really
violent ones at the time so there was a lot of unrest about how do you run businesses properly how do you do
management properly during this time but one thing to consider when you are doing
management is it's a constant balancing act right you really need to be able to
empower individuals give them autonomy and agency to do their best work but if you do that to such a degree you lose
out on the inefficiencies right if everyone wants to write code in one particular way to in every single language we all know what would happen
there but if you go too far to the other extreme and it's everything is standardized you leave no creativity
with people to come up with better solutions so the job of management is really to constantly figure out where
you are in the slider and to find that happiness point and that is not a point that ever stays in the same place for
any duration of time it is a constant struggle to keep that balance in check but I would argue there's a lot of
experience you have as a software developer that can be pulled over into that world of management we all have to
understand how to take really complex systems and abstract them out to make them simpler and to understand how to

communication is just the foundation of everything you can have the best idea in the world if you cannot effectively communicate
that idea it's lost second our business results as developers we are now part of
business in a way in which we can drive real results and it's our responsibility to understand what that looks like and
then finally motivations is absolutely the most complicated one but it is the
force multiplier of management and it's really you really can unlock a lot of efficiency and productivity so I wanted

part of the first female graduating class of Harvard she was the first female consultant at McKinsey and she's
the first example of someone that I feel like came up with a very sort of algorithmic approach to communication
and she did it in a book that she wrote called the pyramid principle and her
argument is effectively we have a tendency sometimes if we are in the weeds to run and try to communicate with
someone with all of those details that we know first and typically what happens is those people will pick up on those
details and then try to bring their own theories to them as quickly as they can it's just how the human brain works and
she was like flip that on its head when you're trying to communicate something if you're trying to come to a decision
with a group of people first and foremost state your point and then you fill in the details underneath it and
she basically has it architected in this way where it's a pyramid the details get more and more fine-grained as you go
down and that's how you architect your argument another thing that she talks
about in the book and that I use honestly all the time emails that's great is this idea of situation
complication question and answer and effectively what the situation does in
any form of communication is it creates this like baseline where it's factual it's we all can agree that X and what
you're doing in that is that you're removing any bias any kind of complication within that initial
statement and everyone can kind of agree on that what you do next is you introduce sort of your opinion the
complication from your frame of reference this is where it's getting tricky and this is what I think is happening from that an answer or

initially in a conversation to get everyone on the same page and then introduce sort of your nuance to it and
it can kind of avoid a lot of initial conflict and I'm gonna reach a little bit into historical here are like

feedback because honestly it's just easier having to say the hard truths to a team oftentimes can be a really really

check between you and the people that are reporting to you of how you're actually giving them feedback in times
we feel like oh you're doing great keep doing what you're doing but in the back of our heads what we know is this person

well-known from basically building up into it he was an engineer by trade and he took

there's tons of things you can do as a business but what matters most is the things that at the end of the day are

there was an interesting sort of approach that was brought forward by the late great political scientist David
Stokes and he kind of looked at companies particularly it was sort of in
the realm of research but he who recognized that there were sort of these four quadrants of projects that were
initiated at companies and he kind of framed them around the great scientists and what you see in that top one with
four this is where you're doing research that doesn't have direct application to
the business so you're not doing like feature four development that's going to be deployed to your customers but perhaps it's paying down a ton of
technical debt or maybe it's a code spike these are sort of or maybe your you know generating a tool kit that can

but it isn't necessarily directly applicable to the business there's another chunk which is basically what
you're delivering every day features delivered to customers every day so that's that pure applied research you
know the use case you know the technology you need to build it and you're building it and then there's that sort of interesting one at the top right
which is pesters quadrant and this has to do with really unique novel thinking this is sort of very ambiguous its
innovative projects its spikes on you know creative ways in which to do
something with technology for the company and so when you look at those quadrant quadrants those are all projects that we sort of see crop up in
our work but what you can also sort of see is that there's kind of different experiences of those projects so for the
bore quadrant oftentimes this work is very detailed it's methodical oftentimes
there's not sort of a driving need from the sales of the marketing team so there can be a little bit more maybe time to

that I think are important for us to recognize as managers now one of that is as managers we really do have a moral
contract with the people that are doing the work we have to respect the work they're doing with their opinions about the work and we have to take the details
that they give us and then draw that into the work that we have to do to streamline the path for them to get that
work done I think the other note is the second bullet point which I see this
happen all the time the unusual worker back in the factory day was somebody that could just haul a

throughout that team if they are the one that can pick up the hard stories from the backlog or you know they take a certain part of the codebase because
they own it again that becomes someone that once they leave all that knowledge
is gone and so instead of making them a force multiplier you basically have made them the gatekeeper of knowledge so I think it he
